Summer months (May and June) are ideal for travelling to Kedarnath because the minimum and maximum temperatures are both about 5C. It is the best time of year to go sightseeing and see temples in kedarnath. The monsoon season, which lasts from July through August, is unfavourable for travel due to the to heavy rains that cause landslides.

Right before winter, in the months of September and October, is also regarded as a wonderful time to visit Kedarnath. The usual high temperature is close to 15 C, and the sky are clear. From October to April, the community has unusually hard winters. The temple is also closed during that time because to the significant snowfall.

I visited the temple in June last year and the weather was quite comfortable to trek and to visit the nearby places as well. Planned the yatra with Manchala Mushafir, liked the service and did the darshan successfully. Now planning to visit the place again this year in May.

The best time to visit Kedarnath temple is between the month of May and October. The place only remains open for a period of six months. The place experiences heavy snowfall in winter such that even the locals are not allowed near the location. During winters the temperate ranges from 5 degrees Celsius to 18 degrees Celsius. Always plan the trips when the climate is pleasant. The best season to do Kedarnath Yatra is when the place experiences the summer season. The temperate ranges from 15-30 degrees Celsius and the climate are warm and pleasant. Never plan the trips during the month between the month from July to August because of the Monsoon climate. The season causes landslides and other problems. Exact dates when the temple will open and close are announced by the government. Choosing the right time to visit the temple will help you to move around the place comfortably. Kedarnath is located in Rudraprayag district and you have to trek from Gaurikund to Kedarnath which is almost 16km in distance.

The doors of Kedarnath temple open usually in the first week of May and closes in November, mostly two days after Diwali on the day of Bhaiya Dooj.

The best time to visit Kedarnath is the summer season, from April to June. The temperature ranges from 15C to 25C. The region experiences mild warmth and cool breeze during the summer, making the weather enjoyable, and the best time to Trek.

July to September is not recommended as the region experiences heavy rainfall. The chances of landslides increase and blockage of routes can cause several delays in the journey, if you are planning, it is advisable to keep buffer days in case you get stuck.

You can also plan Kedarnath Yatra during the pre-winter months, September-October. during these months path leading to the temple gets more beautiful and the weather remains comfortable this month, and it is an ideal time for the Kedarnath Yatra.

Kedarnath in Winter - From October till March. During the winter season, the region experiences sub-zero temperatures and freezing weather. The temple also remains shut during this time due to heavy snowfall. Sometimes there are sunny days too, and the temperature ranges between 0C and 20C. People can visit the Kedarnath region if they wish to explore the enchanting beauty of the snow-clad peaks and the area covered with snow during the winter season from October to April.

I hope that helps!

Happy journey

Jai Shri Kedar! We are in Sonprayag right now! We are about to begin our Kedarnath Dham yatra from here. It is at 9 am. At Sonprayag, I saw a bus standing to leave for Haridwar. I found out that starting at 5 am, at the rate of four buses per hour leave for Haridwar.

In the second half of the day, you cannot leave for Haridwar because there is no bus service available. If you still want to go, you can go till Rudraprayag, on a shared taxi, paying Rs. 500 per person and.... ...from there, you can continue your journey to Haridwar. This is for those who need to travel post-lunch or towards evening. One more thing - I noticed a long line of pilgrims for Biometric registration. The month of May is witness to peak rush to Kedarnath Dham. If you come here for your Biometric exercise, it might take you more than an hour in line. But since we got our Biometric registration done on the way, it took us just 10 minutes and saved an hour here.

You can buy the ticket for a pony ride from the prepaid counter. It will cost you Rs. 2500. One-side! For the return journey, you will need to buy another ticket, for which you will need to wait in a line again. But we don't need a pony because we plan to do this whole yatra on foot. Come let us begin our yatra!

Look at the long line of pilgrims waiting for their jeep ride. We stood in line for 90 minutes. From Sonprayag, you can hire a Bolero, at Rs. 20 per person,.... ...to travel 5kms and reach Gaurikund. The line is so long that, in May month, you need to wait an average of 90 minutes, just like we did. We are seated inside the Bolero and all pilgrims are on their way to Gaurikund. Bholenath ki Jai! (Praise be to Lord Bholenath!) Har Har Mahadev! Once we reached Gaurikund, I found out that.... ...if you hire a pony to ride from here, the one-side cost of that would be Rs. 2300/-. How difficult is the 21km trek to Kedarnath? Looking for someone to share their first hand experiences as I have signed up for it. Thanks.

Shri Kedarnath dham

To start with, I must say, you are Lucky that you are getting an opportunity to visit this Divine Shrine. Not everybody gets a chance to visit such Tirth Sthal. Shri Kedarnath Dham is such a pious place and you just can't get over its Beauty. This place is so Positive and Calm even though it is crowded by a lot of people.

Now talking about the whole experience, keep one thing in mind that , it is not going to be easy' .Tirth Yatra's are never easy. It's only because to attain Moksha in your life.. Remember Lord Shiva always protects his Bhakts, so you do not have to worry about the journey.

The journey starts with Gaurikund sthal. And then it goes on and on .. and on.. on the way you will get to witness natures alluring beauty. Its just treat to the eyes to pass within those ferocious and wild mountains. If you cross rambada spot, and then when you come to the other side of mountains you'll get to see Himalayas peak- shining bright by sun rays falling on it. I faced a lot of struggle during the trek. As you reach near base camp, you'll face some breathing issue, so do carry camphor packs with you. When you finally reach Kedarnath's Base Camp,You'll develop a hope to give all your efforts for the last time to reach that Sacred place. And once you reach the temple, you forget all your pain and struggle. As if Mahadev rewards you by taking away all your pain by successfully reaching his Dwaar.

This place is so Magical and unreal, as if you are just dreaming and won't believe that you are truely present over there. It feels so great to be under the shelter of Mighty Himalayas and witness paradisiacal beauty.

There are Four ways to reach the dham :

  • By Khacchar (donkey and horse mix breed) - It takes 4 - 5 hrs to reach base camp
  • By Doli - Doli is 4 people carrying yatri or 1man carrying yatri. Only childrens , old people or someone who's condition gets weak during the trek are allowed for doli.
  • By self - If you are adventure obsessed person and have great stamina to do this 21km trek , It takes 9 - 12hrs or more than 12hrs depends on your speed.
  • By Helicopter - Easiest way to reach the dham, you reach by just 1520min. If you have booked for 2way trip by helicopter you can return the same day. Because Kedarnath takes 1day to reach and 1day to return.

By Kachhar and self its very difficult. I highly suggest to go by helicopter. But if you want to have Yatra experience. Then go by self rather than Khacchar ride, its very very difficult and scary.

To conclude, Journey was a test, where your physical strength, mental stability and pure faith towards Shiva is being tested.

Even if the path is hard never forget that Shiva is always there With You and For You.

Om Namah Shivaay

How is electrical work installed when building a home with concrete walls?

Concealing of PVC conduits-

Lay out and mark the path of your electrical conduit and electrical boxes as specified in the blueprints.

Work shall be commenced after fixing of steel reinforcement on centering material.

Conduits shall be firmly fixed on steel of RCC work by binding wire. This shall be done for every 4' along the conduit and try to tie it at the point the horizontal and vertical bars cross. Fixing of conduits shall be such that it will remain rigid during casting of slab, beam, and column even after use of vibrator.

Make sure that you leave 12" of the conduit outside of the fo

Concealing of PVC conduits-

Lay out and mark the path of your electrical conduit and electrical boxes as specified in the blueprints.

Work shall be commenced after fixing of steel reinforcement on centering material.

Conduits shall be firmly fixed on steel of RCC work by binding wire. This shall be done for every 4' along the conduit and try to tie it at the point the horizontal and vertical bars cross. Fixing of conduits shall be such that it will remain rigid during casting of slab, beam, and column even after use of vibrator.

Make sure that you leave 12" of the conduit outside of the form so you can join it later to the rest of the buildings electrical supply.

Deep junction boxes and other draw-in boxes shall be such that their open end and cantering material will not have gap in between so as to avoid concrete entering inside even after fixing covers to steel reinforcement; and be filled with dry sand.

Open ends of conduits; to be concealed in walls, shall be provided with couplers / sockets at ends and be flush with bottom of beam, and located at the center of the beam.

As far as possible bunching / grouping of conduits shall be avoided so that it will not affect strength of RCC work especially in beams.

Suitable steel fish wire shall be drawn through in the conduits for drawing of wires later on.

Why should we visit Kedarnath?

This unbelievable thing happened in 2013

In 2013, a mighty glacial lake from a natural dam like formation, that originates River Mandakini on top of snowy Himalayas, suddenly broke and burst open. People heard a thunderous clap 50 kms away. Millions and millions of gallons of icy water, several thousand large boulders, and rocks slid vertically down Himalayas and washed away everything on the way - several towns got wiped away and thousands of people died.

River Mandakini from Himalayas was raging that night for about 10 hours throwing boulders and wiping out everything for at least 200 kms.

The very first human habitation in upper Himalayas was the temple town of Kedarnath at 11400 feet from sea-level. Kedarnath town was almost completely destroyed. The temple on the center of the town was literally the epicenter, and it faced the first attack and full brunt of mother nature.

One day after the event, high altitude helicopter crews surveyed the town. The town did not exist. Himalayas covered it. However to everyone's surprise the 7th century temple, built by ancient Saint Shankaracharya from South India, in the center of the town was standing.

As if by magic, a monstrous boulder (this magic rock) slid down the mighty Himalayas and just stopped short of the 7th century temple at raised ground of 10 feet. It diverted the boulders away from the temple and let minimal water above the rock.

Still water reached 21 feet inside the temple and 3 people inside the temple survived.

A few more feet of sliding, the temple wont be standing. A few less feet of sliding, the temple wont be standing. Nothing around the temple was standing. The boulders and debris that was left behind had a V-formation around just the temple structure. Yes, God split the river that night.

The whole area was ridden with boulders till 2021. Government cleaned it and is rebuilding Kedarnath with safety structures that can divert water flow.

Hindus are grateful to this boulder which protected their ancient temple, built by Adi Shankaracharya. Shankaracharya, walked to Kedarnath and built this temple in 7th century. Kedarnath has no trees or vegetation as nothing grows at that height. He built that temple with resources from 5000 feet below.

(Copied from The Lost Temples' page on Facebook)

Which is best month to visit Kedarnath?

Answer - IN SUMMER The best season to visit Kedarnath is summer when the temperature is moderate and stays between 15-30 degrees Celsius. The sun is warm and there is a gentle cool breeze that makes the day pleasant. With the weather backing you, this is the ideal time to visit Kedarnath temple, Panch Kedar and Chota Char Dham, among other highlights of the area.

Monsoon Season (July-September)

Answer - IN SUMMER The best season to visit Kedarnath is summer when the temperature is moderate and stays between 15-30 degrees Celsius. The sun is warm and there is a gentle cool breeze that makes the day pleasant. With the weather backing you, this is the ideal time to visit Kedarnath temple, Panch Kedar and Chota Char Dham, among other highlights of the area.

Monsoon Season (July-September)

Kedarnath during monsoon is unpredictable. Overall the region doesnt receive much rainfall, but when it does rain heavily, it could lead to landslides and the possibility of roadblocks. Unless you wish to be adventurous, it is best if you avoid this season and plan your spiritual vacation in the summer.

Winter Season (October-March)

When you are visiting the Himalayas in winter, expect freezing cold temperatures. Winter in Kedarnath will test your endurance and leave you breathless in more ways than one. The landscape is beautiful, but you will have to brave temperatures below freezing point at times. The land does see sunny days, but overall, winter is a cold time in Kedarnath.

So my porpoises is Summer is the best season to visit kedarnath temple.

In the last picture in summer season so much people are going to the visiting of Kedarnath and many more item purchases in the market.

What is the best plan to visit Kedarnath from Haridwar?

I visited Kedarnath dham on the 24th of Sept 2019 and i am on my way back from haridwar while writing this..

I reached haridwar on the 22nd from delhi in the evening by jan shatabdi. Checked into a hotel near the bus stand(which is right outside the station). I started next day ,23rd sept,very early at 3:15am. I went to the bus stand and after talking to a few people there i got to know that shared jeep is a better option to reach gaurikund than bus. But you will have to break your journey into parts.

So i took a shared jeep till Rudraprayag for rs 350 and it took me 6 hrs 30 mins to reach there

I visited Kedarnath dham on the 24th of Sept 2019 and i am on my way back from haridwar while writing this..

I reached haridwar on the 22nd from delhi in the evening by jan shatabdi. Checked into a hotel near the bus stand(which is right outside the station). I started next day ,23rd sept,very early at 3:15am. I went to the bus stand and after talking to a few people there i got to know that shared jeep is a better option to reach gaurikund than bus. But you will have to break your journey into parts.

So i took a shared jeep till Rudraprayag for rs 350 and it took me 6 hrs 30 mins to reach there. Then, just where i got dropped at Rudraprayag, i took another jeep towards Guptkashi for rs100 and it took 3 hrs . Then again from my drop point i got a jeep towards Sonprayag for rs150 and it took 1hr 30 mins (the road on this route is terrible). From Sonprayag a jeep took me to Gaurikund which is just 5 kms for rs20.

I stayed the night at Gaurikund. Cost of hotel was rs300. Next morning i started my trek towards the temple at 7 am and it took me 9 hrs 30 mins to reach there. I returned on the 25th back to Gaurikund and it took 5 hrs 15 mins to trek down.

The trek is very very tiring but it is a priceless feeling when you see the first glimpse of the temple surrounded by snow clad mountains.

So the best and the cheapest way to go is by shared jeep

HaridwarRudraprayagGuptkashiSonprayagGaurikund.. Time taken 12 hrs approx.

Where are the best places to visit in Kedarnath?

Breath-taking snow-covered Himalayan mountains, a 1000-year-old temple invoking deep emotions, an enveloping divine aura, this is Kedarnath- the Land of the Gods. Kedarnath lies at a height of 3584 meters, close to the source of the holy Mandakini river. Named after king Kedar from the Satya Yuga, Kedarnath is one of the four Chota char Dham that also includes Badrinath, Gangotri, and Yamunotri. Everyone, once in their lifetime, must give this one of the most sacred places on earth a visit. Before you go, take note of these 10 best places to visit in Kedarnath.

18 Places To Visit In Kedarnath

Here are the 18 best places to visit in Kedarnath on your next vacation to Uttarakhand and have a great time away from the hustle-bustle. These places offer the finest views and also let travelers immerse themselves in religious activities.

  • Kedarnath Temple
  • Bhairavnath Temple
  • Vasuki Tal
  • Sonprayag
  • Shankaracharya Samadhi
  • Chandrashila
  • Gaurikund
  • Triyuginarayan Temple
  • Guptakashi
  • Chorabari Tal
  • Tungnath Temple
  • Rudranath Temple
  • Madhyamaheshwar Temple
  • Kalpeshwar Temple
  • Mayali Pass Trek
  • Ukhimath
  • Agastmuni
  • Deoria Taal

Which is the best way to reach Kedarnath Yatra?

Right now it's not applicable but soon the devotees of God Shiva will be able to visit the Kedarnath temple with more comfort and in less time as the process of building a ropeway to this Hindu holy shrine has begun.

The Detailed Project Reports (DPR) for ropeways to Kedarnath and Hemkund Sahib are ready.

The forest land transfer process for Sonprayag-Gaurikund-Kedarnath and Govind ghat-Ghangaria-Hemkund ropeway projects has begun.

The length of the Sonprayag-Gaurikund-Kedarnath ropeway project will be 13 km, and the estimated cost of the project will be over Rs 985 crore.

Set to be the longest ro

Right now it's not applicable but soon the devotees of God Shiva will be able to visit the Kedarnath temple with more comfort and in less time as the process of building a ropeway to this Hindu holy shrine has begun.

The Detailed Project Reports (DPR) for ropeways to Kedarnath and Hemkund Sahib are ready.

The forest land transfer process for Sonprayag-Gaurikund-Kedarnath and Govind ghat-Ghangaria-Hemkund ropeway projects has begun.

The length of the Sonprayag-Gaurikund-Kedarnath ropeway project will be 13 km, and the estimated cost of the project will be over Rs 985 crore.

Set to be the longest ropeway in the world at an altitude of 11,500 feet above sea level, it will significantly reduce the time taken by pilgrims to reach the Kedarnath shrine in Rudraprayag district. The ropeway will enable them to travel from Sonprayag to Kedarnath in 60 minutes.

Thank you for the A2A Sir, as I get to re-live my Kedarnath pilgrimage.

During the first visit..

It felt like the devotion, meditation, love and compassion of several births burst through me all at once.

I was in ecstatic tears throughout my time there. totally mad and uncontrolled.

A Sadhu wearing just a dhoti in that cold, took me to his small place and prepared dinner- Rasam Rice, knowing I am coming from Chennai. So, I ate the food cooked from his begging. I felt like eating from the hands of Mahadev, and was easily in trance.

The whole night I was sleeping on a bench in the open watching the stars and Kedar dome, because I couldnt sleep inside room due to less oxygen.

I was overcome by devotion again and again just in awe thinking, This is the land of Mahadev where the Holy saints came walking from all over India since ancient times, and I am in his lap tonight- raw and rugged I was overcome with devotion in His Grace again and again.

The next morning at 5 AM, I went inside the temple and sat for meditation. The Sadhu was sitting outside looking for me. He took me inside the temple and made me sit to the right of the Nandi.

I sat and energies were flowing for a while, although I am not a great fan. I then surrendered and dissolved in Mahadev.

Peace and Bliss.

Coming outside the temple, I was laughing like a Shivas demon, and would have willingly offered me to death ecstatically.

Jai Bholanath.

Himalayas: Which is the best way to go to kedarnath?

ToI have recently visited Kedarnath with my family. Let me share my experience.

We started from Haridwar via car.Bus transport is also available from Haridwar. One has to change transport at Sonprayag as other vehicles are not allowed beyond that. One has to cross bridge over Mandakini by foot and avail Maxx cars (Rs20/person) to reach Gourikund. The motorable road is till Gourikund only.Then there are three options.

  1. Walk 16kms to reach Kedar.The way is steep.People thinking to walk should have ample time at hand and a stick.

2. One can book horse ride too.The government approved rate is Rs. 1800/person for upward journey and Rs. 1100/person for downward journey.The horse has tendency to go towards the valley side.Ask your horseman to hold the rope tightly.Horsemen sometimes let that go for various reasons.

3. One can book duli too.Thats going on another persons shoulder/head.

I took horse as I went with my parents and they couldnot walk that far.

From my personal experience I would say avoid duli as its very painful for the person who takes you.Walking is best if you are fit.Horse is for those cant walk.

There are ample helicopter service providers as well, both government and private.Helipads are there at Phata,Sersi etc.

But one will miss the scenic beauty if one rides the helicopter.The natural beauty on the way is breathtaking and one is very unlucky to miss it.

The majestic temple of Kedarnath lies in the town of Kedarnath in Uttarakhand. It is located at an elevation of 3600 meters above the sea level in the Garhwal mountain range, which is close to the Mandakini River and is dedicated to Lord Shiva.

The best time to visit the temple is between the last week of April and the first week of November as it is during this time that the weather is most conductive for such visits.The temple structure is open from 4 am in the morning till 9 pm at night daily. Devotees can touch the Shiva Lingam and also take part in the Abhishekam. Between 3 pm and 5 pm the temple is closed.

When should people go to Kedarnath?

Kedarnath temple reopens after winter. And that is the best time to visit. The weather is very enjoyable at that time. So do the scenic beauty of the area.

Raj Sharma
1y

If you are planning a trip of your own Char Dham tour package, one of the most important things to know is when to plan a trip and the best time to visit.

Summer

After a harsh winter, spring and summer are beautiful in the mountains, with the valleys in full bloom with great varieties of flowers. Summers from April to June are the best time to visit Kedarnath temple.

Monsoon

Monsoons arrive at the Char Dham around the end of June and continue till September end. With heavy rains, landslides and flooding due to swollen rivers are quite common during the monsoon season and travelling is really not advisable.

Another window of a good season to visit arrives in the end of September to mid-November.

Winters

Winters arrive at the end of November and last up to March. Due to heavy snowing and sub-zero temperature, darshan is stopped after Diwali. The Char Dham temples open their gates for darshan only in spring, during the Hindu festival of Akshaya Tritiya.

What are the best months to visit Kedarnath?

The best time to visit Kedarnath is from May to June and from September to November. During these months, the weather is pleasant, and the skies are clear, making it ideal for sightseeing and trekking. However, the temple is closed during the monsoon season (July to August) due to the risk of landslides and heavy rainfall.

The best time to visit Kedarnath is from May to June and from September to November. During these months, the weather is pleasant, and the skies are clear, making it ideal for sightseeing and trekking. However, the temple is closed during the monsoon season (July to August) due to the risk of landslides and heavy rainfall.

Where should I go first for going to Kedarnath from Rishikesh?

Hello There!!!

Here are the things which you can follow to visit Kedarnath -

Case 1 -

From Rishikesh, you can take a shared GMOU bus to Sonprayag which runs early morning around 5 AM. Once you can reach the Sonprayag you can take a shared taxi till Govindghat. Gaurikund is the place where the actual trek starts for Kedarnath. The total distance of the trek is around 16 km which takes around 46 hours depends on your speed.

Rishikesh - 212km-> Sonprayag - 4km-> Gaurikund - 16Km Trek ->Kedarnath

Case 2 -

If you miss the early morning bus to Sonprayag then you can take a bus to Rudraprayag. From Rudraprayag, you can take a shared taxi or cab to Sonprayag. Sonprayag is around 70 km from Rudraprayag which would take approx 3 hours. Once you reach Sonprayag you can take local transport till Gaurikund and from there you can continue the trek to Kedarnath.

Rishikesh - 142 km-> Rudrprayag - 72 Km -> Sonprayag - 4 Km-> Gaurikund - 16 Km Trek ->Kedarnath

Hope it helps

What are some nice places to visit near Kedarnath?

Vasuki Tal

A lake situated at 4135 m above sea level, Vasuki Tal promises jaw-dropping views of the neighbouring Chaukhamba peaks. The journey to this Tal is an absolute joy for trekkers. The Chaturangi and Vasuki Glaciers also show up on the road to the Tal. Visitors can see the Brahma Kamal and other Himalayan florae flourishing about the calm lake, creating a peaceful vibration in the area.

Shankaracharya Samadhi

Shankaracharya Samadhi, the burial chamber of Adi Guru Shankaracharya, is one of the highly visited tourist spots in the area. It can be found behind the Kedarnath Temple. Currently, there is a hot spring here that is said to have been created by Shankara himself, to reduce the woes faced by his disciples due to the extreme weather conditions.

Agastyamuni

20 km from Rudraprayag, Agastyamuni is a very famous religious destination in Uttarakhand. Nestled at 1000 m above sea-level, it is situated along the bank of the lovely Mandakini River. Popular for the temple named after Sage Agastya, it is believed that he mediated here for a year. Tourists also indulge in fishing on the banks of the Mandakini River.

Chandrashila

Located 4000 metres above sea-level, the name Chandrashila means Moon Rock. It is the peak of Chandranath Parvat, where the Tungnath Temple of Panch Kedar is positioned. The royal Chandrashila peak functions as a lookout that offers stunning panoramic views of the Greater Himalayas.

Sonprayag

  • 1829 metres above sea-level, it is the spot where Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati were wedded. Bordered by Mother Natures abundance and magnificent snowy mountaintops, this is also where the River Mandakini encounters River Basuki, making for a beautiful tourist destination.
  • Bhairavnath Temple

Positioned 3 km after the sacred caverns of Vaishno Devi, Bhairavnath Temple is devoted to Baba Bhairavnath, built at the location where he took his final breath. Located in the Bhairav Ghati, the path to the shrine is dangerous. The landscape surrounding the temple is charming and makes for a worthwhile journey.

Gaurikund

Gaurikund is the beginning of the 16 km hike to the holy memorial of Kedarnath. It is located at an altitude of 1,982 metres above sea level. It is named after Parvati, the wife of Lord Shiva. It is surrounded by lush green forests and enjoys gorgeous views. It is one of the top tourist spots in the area and a focal point for the Char Dham journey.

What is a good itinerary for a two week trip to Northern India?

Hi,

February and onwards is usually the end of winter and the beginning of spring: the best time to visit North India. I would recommend taking time from your trip to experience the festivity of colors called Holi. My recommended itinerary would be:

1. Hit Rajasthan first: The land of forts and deserts. The best time to visit Rajasthan is during the winter, from the end of November. Your timing (if you land in India around the end of Feb) coincides with the end of winter, onwards from which Rajasthan gets hotter with the eventual arrival of summer. Visit the various forts - primarily, the cities

Hi,

February and onwards is usually the end of winter and the beginning of spring: the best time to visit North India. I would recommend taking time from your trip to experience the festivity of colors called Holi. My recommended itinerary would be:

1. Hit Rajasthan first: The land of forts and deserts. The best time to visit Rajasthan is during the winter, from the end of November. Your timing (if you land in India around the end of Feb) coincides with the end of winter, onwards from which Rajasthan gets hotter with the eventual arrival of summer. Visit the various forts - primarily, the cities of Jaipur, Bikaner, Jodhpur, and Jaisalmer. Udaipur is a lake city and one Indias most beautiful cities. Try out the Laal Maas - a local delicacy.

Fly into Delhi, take a train or a bus or cab to Jaipur and start your travel from there. I would recommend around 6-8 days in Rajasthan, assuming you have two weeks at hand.

If you have time, spend 2-3 days in Delhi before heading to Rajasthan. Delhi is full of history and can lovely to visit. Intach conducts some pretty interesting walking tours - places where normal tourists and locals hardly go or are even aware of. Feb would have amazing weather, ideal for strolling in the afternoon sun.

For food in Delhi, I would look at Karim's and Al Jawahar, and in fact Old Delhi as such. Karim's is more famous, while Al Jawahar( just next door to Karim's) is my preferred one. They are situated in Old Delhi and hence approaching these places may not feel comforting, but the restaurants themselves are pretty safe. You will find a pretty good mix of locals, non-local Indians and foreigners there. Karim's has many branches in other parts of Delhi, too - avoid them. They are expensive and food aint the same. Try out the kulfi and other local desserts and the paan. You should also try Rajinder's dhaba - near Safdarjung Enclave and serves amazing non-vegetarian stuff. You may have to queue up for dinner though.

  1. If you want to see Holi - from Rajasthan, move to a city near Agra called Mathura. Mathura and a small city nearby called Vrindavan are religious towns dedicated to Lord Krishna. They are the best places in the country to be for the festival of Holi. Do try bhaang, a must-have during Holi. Would recommend 2-3 days, including the one full day dedicated to Holi.
  2. If Holi is not in your plans, move to Agra and Fatehpur Sikri next. The best time to visit Taj Mahal is early morning. Check out the timings and make sure you are one of the first visitors to the Taj. The marble will be smooth and cold to walk onto (it gets really hot as the day progresses) and the weather nice for admiring the monument. As the day progresses, it becomes hot and extremely crowded. In the daytime, you can visit the Agra fort and Fatehpur Sikri. Spend around 2 days in Agra. Try the local sweet called Petha, though it can be on the sweet side.
  3. From Delhi, take a long overnight bus journey or a flight (usually the costlier option) to reach Manali. Manali opens the door to further reach Leh and Ladakh (which unfortunately gets road cleared from approx. June onwards). Manali is a home to some of the world's best cannabis. You would find a lot of foreigners from all over the world - and if you are game, give it a shot.
  4. Another course of action would be to visit the Himalayas in Uttarakhand. Take a train or bus from Delhi and reach Haridwar. Stay 2-3 days, visit the nearby cities like Rishikesh, Baba Ramdev's Patanjali Ashram, attend the Ganga Aarti in the evening on the banks of river Ganges and raft on the river during the day.
  5. From Haridwar, move on to the Himalayas. You can visit Mussorie- called the Queen of Hills in India. Or move towards treks such as Valley of Flowers.
  6. Post the Himalayas - move on to Varanasi and Allahabad. And attain salvation :)
Sumit Kudiyal
Lives in Rishikesh, Uttarakhand, India 6y

When is the best time to visit Kedarnath Dham?

Kedarnath Temple is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is located on the Garhwal Himalayan range near the Mandakini river in the state of Uttarakhand, India.

Due to extreme weather conditions, the temple is open and can be visited by general public only between the months of April (Akshaya Tritiya) and November (Kartik Purnima, the autumn full moon).

Kedarnath Temple is a famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. It is located on the Garhwal Himalayan range near the Mandakini river in the state of Uttarakhand, India.

The best time to visit Kedarnath, a Hindu pilgrimage site in the Indian state of Uttarakhand, depends on your personal preferences and the type of experience you are looking for.

If you want to experience the beauty of the surrounding snow-capped mountains, the best time to visit Kedarnath is during the summer months of May to June, or the autumn months of September to October. These months offer pleasant weather, with temperatures ranging from 15C to 25C.

If you want to see the area covered in snow, the winter months of November to April are the best time to visit. However, keep in mind that the temperature can drop to below freezing and the roads may be closed due to heavy snowfall.

It is important to note that the Kedarnath temple is only open from April to November, as it is closed during the winter months due to heavy snowfall.

The best time to visit Kedarnath, a Hindu pilgrimage site located in the Indian state of Uttarakhand, depends on what you're looking to experience.

The best time to visit Kedarnath, a Hindu pilgrimage site located in the Indian state of Uttarakhand, depends on what you're looking to experience.

  • The peak season for visiting Kedarnath is during the months of May to October, when the weather is mild and the roads are open. This is the best time to visit if you're looking to do the Kedarnath trek, as the snow has melted and the trails are clear.
  • If you're looking to experience the spiritual significance of Kedarnath, then the best time to visit would be during the Kedarnath Yatra, which usually takes place in the months of May to June. During this time, the temple is open for devotees and there are many religious ceremonies and rituals taking place.
  • For those who want to avoid the crowds, the best time to visit would be in the months of November to April. During this time, the temple is closed and the weather is harsh and the trek is closed. But this is the best time for nature lovers as the snow covered Himalayas are mesmerizing.

Please note that the dates of the Yatra can vary every year and are decided by the temple committee. Also, the trek to Kedarnath is also closed during monsoons due to the heavy rainfall and landslides. It's always best to check the current situation before planning your trip.

Kedarnath is a popular Hindu pilgrimage site located in the Indian state of Uttarakhand. The temple, dedicated to Lord Shiva, is one of the four sacred shrines in the Hindu religion known as the Char Dham. The temple is situated at an altitude of 3,583 meters above sea level and is surrounded by the majestic Himalayan range.

The best time to visit Kedarnath is between May and June, when the snow melts and the temperature is mild. The trek to the temple is open during this time, and visitors can enjoy the beautiful landscapes and lush greenery. The monsoon season, between July and August, should be avoided as the trek can become treacherous due to heavy rainfall and landslides.

Between September and October, the weather is pleasant and the crowds are less, making it a good time to visit. However, it is important to note that the temple closes for the winter season in October and reopens in April. During this time, the temple is covered in snow and the trek is closed due to extreme weather conditions.

The Char Dham Yatra, which includes a visit to Kedarnath, is considered to be one of the most sacred journeys in Hinduism. The yatra takes place every year and attracts a large number of visitors. The best time to visit Kedarnath, a Hindu temple town located in the Indian state of Uttarakhand, is between May and June, and September to November. During these months, the weather is pleasant, and the skies are clear, offering breathtaking views of the surrounding mountains.

May to June is ideal for trekking, as the snow has melted, and the trails are clear. September to November is the peak season for tourists, as the weather is ideal, and the temple is open to the public.

Avoid visiting Kedarnath during the monsoon season, which starts in July and lasts until August, as the region is prone to heavy rainfall and landslides, which can make travel difficult. What is the best season/time to visit Kedarnath?

The best time for a trek in Kedarnath, India, depends on the type of trek you want to undertake. Kedarnath is a popular destination for trekking and is located in the Himalayan range of Uttarakhand.

  1. Summer (April to June): This is the best time for trekking in Kedarnath if you want to avoid the snow and enjoy clear skies. The temperature during this time is pleasant, making it a good time for a trek.
  2. Monsoon (July to September): The monsoon season is not ideal for trekking in Kedarnath as the trail can be slippery and the weather can be unpredictable.
  3. Winter (October to March): Winter is the best time to see the snow-capped peaks of Kedarnath, but the temperature can be very cold, making it challenging for some people to trek.

It is recommended to plan your trek in Kedarnath well in advance, taking into consideration the weather and trail conditions. You should also be prepared for the high altitude and carry necessary gear, including warm clothing, waterproof gear, and a first-aid kit. It's also a good idea to hire a local guide to help you navigate the trail and ensure a safe and enjoyable experience.

It is one of the four Chaar Dhaam, and is considered to be a very sacred place for devotees. Kedarnath is situated at a height of 3,584 meters, and is surrounded by the breathtaking Himalayan Mountains. The best time to visit Kedarnath is during the period between May and October.

During this period, the weather is pleasant and the temperature ranges from 10C to 25C. This is the ideal time to visit the shrine as the weather is conducive for long treks and sightseeing.

Kedarnath is one of the most popular pilgrimage sites in India and has been attracting devotees from all over the world for centuries. Located in Uttarakhand, it is one of the Chardhams, or the four most important Hindu pilgrimage sites in the country. The other three Chardhams are Gangotri, Yamunotri and Badrinath, all of which are located in the same region. Kedarnath is an important part of the Char Dham Yatra, a spiritual journey that is believed to cleanse ones soul and provide moksha or liberation from the cycle of birth and death.

It is believed that a visit to Kedarnath will bring one closer to Lord Shiva, one of the most revered Hindu gods. The area is home to the temple of Lord Shiva, which is considered to be one of the most sacred shrines in the country.

Generally, the best time to visit Kedarnath is from April to November when the weather is pleasant, and the pilgrimage season is in full swing. During these months, the temperature ranges from 5C to 20C, making it ideal for trekking and sightseeing. However, the monsoon season from July to September brings heavy rainfall, landslides, and roadblocks, making it challenging to reach Kedarnath. The winter season from December to March brings heavy snowfall, making the region inaccessible. Therefore, it is advisable to plan your trip from delhi to kedarnath accordingly.

The best time to visit Kedarnath depends on your preferences and what you want to experience during your trip.

Kedarnath is located in the Indian state of Uttarakhand and is a popular pilgrimage destination for Hindus. The temple is located at an altitude of over 3500 meters in the midst of the majestic Himalayan mountains, which can make it difficult to access during certain times of the year.

Typically, the Kedarnath temple is open to visitors from late April to early November. The summer months of May, June, and July are considered the peak season for tourism in Kedarnath due to the mild weather and clear skies. The monsoon season from July to September can be risky due to the possibility of landslides and floods, but the landscape is lush and green during this time.

The months of October and November are considered the shoulder season, and while the weather is colder and there is a chance of snowfall, the views of the snow-capped peaks are breathtaking.

It is important to keep in mind that the temple is closed during the winter months from November to April due to heavy snowfall and extreme weather conditions.

Therefore, if you are planning a trip to Kedarnath, it is best to plan it between late April and early November when the temple is open, and the weather is favorable for traveling.

How can I visit Kedarnath on a budget with safety?

To make sure the trip to kedarnath is hassel free I would recommend you to make booking along with a travel agency like Manchala Mushafir. They take care of everything right from hotel bookings to providing you with the tour guides. My last trip to Kedarnath was the most spiritually enriching and breathtakingly beautiful experience. On my visit to the Kedarnath Temple the view against the backdrop of the beautiful Himalayas, the glaciers, and alpine forests was mesmerizing.

The journey to Kedarnath Temple starts from the town of Gaurikund, which is located at an altitude of 1,982 meters. From Gaurikund, the trek to Kedarnath is around 14 kilometers and takes about 5 to 7 hours to complete. The trek is steep and rocky, and passes through beautiful landscapes of the Himalayas, including lush green forests, sparkling streams and waterfalls. Along the way, there are several rest stations and dhabas (tea shops) where one can rest and refresh themselves.

If I am travelling in Kedarnath, what kind of preparation should be ready?

Img Src- naidunia.com

  1. Be of average fitness. Do some walking and cardio at least a month before trip, so you are in better shape to explore around. You can try incline walk on a treadmill.
  2. There is a Bhairav temple, on a short trek to the right of the main temple. This is awesome, and you need to be fit due to the additional altitude.
  3. If you are above forties, better to do a cardio and general check up before the trip.
  4. Don't go straight from Rishikesh to Kedarnath the same day. Have at least two night stays in between for better acclimatisation. The Oxygen is low up there.
  5. Keep some tablets for alt

Img Src- naidunia.com

  1. Be of average fitness. Do some walking and cardio at least a month before trip, so you are in better shape to explore around. You can try incline walk on a treadmill.
  2. There is a Bhairav temple, on a short trek to the right of the main temple. This is awesome, and you need to be fit due to the additional altitude.
  3. If you are above forties, better to do a cardio and general check up before the trip.
  4. Don't go straight from Rishikesh to Kedarnath the same day. Have at least two night stays in between for better acclimatisation. The Oxygen is low up there.
  5. Keep some tablets for altitude sickness.
  6. Keep full and proper winter gear as the weather may turn anyways in the high altitudes.
  7. Avoid travelling during monsoon months, as the region is prone to heavy rain, floods and landslides.
  8. Dont drink the water from any falls on the way. You don't know what the water is washing down from the upper villages. Use bottled water you bought from the valleys. Or you can get hot water from the small shops throughout the way.
  9. Keep sanitising and washing your hands, even after Covid. Somehow, I see a lot of mountain people sick with cold these days. Donno what happened to their traditional immunity? So take care.
  10. If you are old, or have history of altitude sickness, you can use the short helicopter ride on top, just avoiding the trek. You can return from Kedarnath to a lower altitude, may be Sitapur, the same day.
  11. If you are reasonably fit, I will suggest onward on top, in helicopter, and return by trekking down. You can even stay on Bhimbali camps on the way down. It is another experience in itself.

Jai Bholenath.

What's the best month to visit Bali, Indonesia?

I'll tell the pros and cons for every month.

January, February: the weather is overcast, rainy. Not good for beach going, but if you wanted culture this is your time. Hotels are cheap.

March: huge wave, great for surfing, and few rains

April: great for beach goers, good condition for diving, usually their Quiet holiday happened around April. Enjoy it by immersing your spirituality.

June, August: optimal condition for diving, watching sunset or sunrise, great for trekking and mountaineering.

July: while the weather are great, it is school holiday season and local tourists will be everywhere. Not goo

I'll tell the pros and cons for every month.

January, February: the weather is overcast, rainy. Not good for beach going, but if you wanted culture this is your time. Hotels are cheap.

March: huge wave, great for surfing, and few rains

April: great for beach goers, good condition for diving, usually their Quiet holiday happened around April. Enjoy it by immersing your spirituality.

June, August: optimal condition for diving, watching sunset or sunrise, great for trekking and mountaineering.

July: while the weather are great, it is school holiday season and local tourists will be everywhere. Not good for escaping yourself.

September, October: it started to get really hot and humid, people usually caught influenza these days. If you wanted to get some tan, it's your time.

November, December: a few short rains but otherwise great. Special note, in December things are getting expensive due to Christmas and new year holiday.

Ramadan: local tourists will flock to Bali and you'll have hard time to find cheap hotels.

How can I cover Haridwar, Rishikesh, Badrinath, and Kedarnath?

Hey Varsha, Hope youre doing well.

You didnt mention how many days you have and whats your starting point. Im supposing you are coming from Delhi and have lots of time to explore.

Here is the itinerary -

Day 1 -Delhi-Haridwar (Drive -240 Km /05 Hours Approx.)

Day 2 - Haridwar- Guptkashi (Drive - 210 Kms/07 hr approx.)

Day 3 - Guptkashi- Gaurikund (Drive- 30 Kms/45 mins approx) Gaurikund- Kedarnath (17 Kms trek)

Day 4 - Kedarnath-Guptkashi (Trek back to Gaurikund & Drive - 120 Kms/05 hrs approx.)

Day 5 - Guptkashi- Badrinath (Drive 85 Kms/ 03 hr approx.)

Day 6 - Badrinath- Rudraprayag (Drive - 160 Kms/05 hr approx.)

Day 7 - Rudraprayag- Rishikesh (Drive - 141 Kms/04 hr approx.)

Day 8 - Rishikesh sightseeing

Day 9 - Rishikesh to Delhi (230 Km/06 hours approx)

(you can save one day if you take Heli for Kedarnath and can add more days in any destination as per your requirement)

So to come to Haridwar you can take any public transport (bus, train, cab or flight to Dehradun) as per your convenience. So once you reach Haridwar you can go for evening sightseeing and take stay on the very first day.

For the rest of the journey, I would suggest you hire any cab for the rest of your trip bcz travelling in public transport is more time consuming, and hectic.

If you still have any queries or doubt you can directly DM me or can call me.

How do I visit Kedarnath Dham easily?

Kedarnath Dham can be visited by taking bus to Sonprayag/ Guptkashi from Haridwar/ Delhi. From Sonprayag, shared taxi available till Gaurikund. Kedarnath Dham could be reach after 18 kms trek from Gaurikund. Helicopter service to Kedarnath Dham are also available from Sersi, Pahata & Guptkash.
